I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $55,000,000 to Kochi Metro Rail Limited (KMRL) for Kochi Metro Extension Project in India. 
The report also describes the proposed administration of a loan of up to $50,000,000 to be provided 
by the Leading Asia's Private Infrastructure Fund, also known as “Leading Asia’s Private Sector 
Infrastructure Fund” (LEAP),1 and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the administration of the loan. 
 
2.  The project entails the extension of the existing 25.16 kilometers (km) of metro rail (built in 
phase 1) in Kochi, in India's state of Kerala in a phased manner, comprising (i) phase 1A from 
Petta—the phase 1 terminal station—to S.N Junction, for a length of 2.0 km; and (ii) phase 1B from 
S.N Junction to Tripunithura, where the metro rail connects to the existing long-distance railway 
station, for a length of 1.2 km. The project will improve mobility, livability, and the urban environment 
by supporting the provision of a clean, safe, disaster-resilient, and inclusive transport system. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
3.  Project identification. An inclusive and sustainable urban transport system is critical for 
the smooth functioning of cities. India’s National Urban Transport Policy in 2006 projected an 
increase in the country’s urban population from about 285 million in 2001 to about 473 million in 
2021, and 805 million in 2050.2 This rapid urbanization led to a sharp increase in traffic—between 
2009 and 2019, the number of registered vehicles grew at a compound annual rate of 9.9%3—and 
severely constrained urban road capacity, resulting in heavy congestion and air pollution, and 
compromised  road  safety.  The  Government  of  India  committed  to  improve  the  situation  by 
implementing its urban transport policy (footnote 2), which prioritizes sustainable public transport. 
As of 31 March 2021, more than 700 km of metro railway networks are operational in 18 cities 
across India. An additional 1,010 km are under construction, including in nine more cities.4 The 
Metro Rail Policy (2017) lays down guidelines and norms for the metro rail development that cater 
to passenger services in a large urban agglomerate or metropolitan area.5 
 
4.  Kochi is the largest and most densely populated city in Kerala, and is often called the 
economic capital since its industrial and financial activities are driving Kerala's economy. According 
to the 2011 census, the city alone had a population of 677,000, while the greater metropolitan area 
numbered 2.1 million. The state's transport infrastructure consists of about 273,000 km of road; 
1,588 km of railways; 1,687 km of inland waterways; 18 ports; and 25,449 buses. 6 During peak 
hours, some of these services are heavily saturated. 
 
5.  Project  design.  The  metro  rail  system  in  Kochi  is  operated  by  KMRL,  which  was 
incorporated in 2011 to develop and operate nonmotorized public transport projects in the city. The 
Government of India and Kerala each own 50% of shares in KMRL. Phase 1 construction began in

6.  Borrower and guarantor. For fiscal year (FY) 2020, KMRL reported revenue of ₹940 
million, an increase of 17% from ₹801 million in FY2019. Net loss was ₹3,098 million in FY2020, 
9% higher than ₹2,849 million in FY2019. As of 31 March 2020, KMRL’s total equity was ₹23.3 
billion, and short- and long-term borrowings were ₹32.4 billion. Net losses are currently being 
incurred, because after commissioning of phase 1, passenger numbers had not yet stabilized when 
the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic struck. (Confidential information deleted.) Kerala 
has the 11th highest gross state domestic product in India. The state also has the ninth highest per 
capita income in the country—about 1.6 times the national average. The state government is 
internationally rated BB- by Standard & Poor’s7 and BB by Fitch Ratings.8 
 
7.  Corporate governance and state-owned enterprise reform. Key constraints which public 
transportation projects face include ensuring financial sustainability while maintaining affordable 
ticket prices and high quality of service to enable modal shift. Commercial financing is normally not 
contemplated for such projects as the need to keep tickets affordable leads to farebox revenues 
not  being  adequate  to  service  such  loans,  leading  to  significant—and  occasionally   
unsustainable—dependence on subsidies to meet debt service. KMRL had therefore financed 
phase 1 by a traditional sovereign guaranteed loan from Agence Française de Développement. 
However, for the phase 1A and 1B extension, KMRL decided to borrow commercially, to minimize 
dependence on limited state government’s sovereign guarantee headroom that could be utilized 
for more pressing, developmental projects. (Confidential information deleted.) Since both KMRL 
and  the  state  government  have  to  comply  with  stringent  financial  covenants  (Confidential 
information deleted.), the proposed loan will impose meaningful financial and fiscal discipline on 
the borrower and the guarantor—aimed at sustained financial reform over the loan life.  
 
8.  Borrowing on a nonsovereign basis from ADB, and going through the intensive financial, 
legal and credit due diligence will also enable KMRL to build capacity to raise market-based finance 
for its future capital expenditure, aimed at reducing financial dependence on the state government. 
Financial structuring of the proposed loan, and reporting and disclosure requirements are similar 
to those for a private sector entity, which will require KMRL to enhance its corporate governance. 
In addition, through extensive engagement with KMRL, in partnership with South Asia Department 
(SARD), best in class environmental and social (E&S) standards, and robust gender related 
aspects, have been included in project design, compliance with which will lead to meaningful 
capacity building. 
 
9.  COVID-19  impact.  With  the  outbreak  of  COVID-19  and  the  consequent  lockdown 
measures,  KMRL  had  to  suspend  its  operations  from  24  March  to  7  September  2020. 
(Confidential information deleted.) The impact on the implementation of the project will be 
limited. (Confidential information deleted.)

B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
12.  Impact. The project impact is aligned with the Government of India’s Metro Rail Policy 2017, 
which targets improvements to public transport in Indian cities by implementing mass transit 
systems (footnote 5). 
 
13.  Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: operations of clean mass transport 
system expanded. 
 
14.  Outputs. The outputs of the project are (i) disaster-resilient Kochi metro rail expanded, 
(ii) gender-inclusive  local  employment  generated,  and  (iii) gender  inclusiveness  of  stations 
enhanced. 
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
15.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project is consistent with four 
of the seven operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030: (i) addressing remaining poverty and 
reducing inequalities; (ii) making cities more livable; (iii) tackling climate change, building climate 
and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability; and (iv) accelerating progress 
in gender equality.9 The project is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2018–2022 
for India, specifically pillar 2: providing inclusive access to infrastructure networks and social 
services by improving the infrastructure bottlenecks in lagging regions.10 
 
16.  Consistency with sector strategy and related ADB operations. The project is consistent 
with two elements of ADB's Sustainable Transport Initiative: scaling up urban transport, and 
addressing climate change in transport.11 
 
D.  Project Cost and Financing Plan

19.  Climate change adaptation and mitigation. The climate change assessment revealed 
medium overall risk for the project. Kochi is projected to experience increasingly higher average 
temperatures and an increasing occurrence of extreme weather events. The project includes 
modern design and technology, such as stack effect ventilation on station roofs to create airflow. 
To minimize flooding, the plinth level of the network is set above high-flood levels, and the retention 
capacity of existing storm drains is augmented. (Confidential information deleted.) The project will 
contribute to climate change mitigation because it will result in a modal shift from road to rail, which 
is a cleaner mode of transport. Hence, the entire $105 million of ADB financing (including from 
LEAP) is eligible for climate financing—primarily mitigation with a small amount for adaptation.

G.  Unique Features 
22.  This project is the first nonsovereign transaction jointly processed by ADB’s Private Sector 
Operations Department (PSOD) and SARD in the transport sector in India and is categorized as a 
One ADB collaboration.12 SARD and PSOD jointly identified the project and leveraged their 
respective areas of expertise. SARD was engaged in sector policy dialogue and provided technical 
assistance on safeguard due diligence and financial modeling. PSOD is primarily responsible for 
financial structuring and commercial due diligence. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
A.  The Assistance 
23.  ADB’s assistance will comprise (i) a loan of up to $55 million, and (ii) administration of a loan 
of up to $50 million from LEAP. (Confidential information deleted.) 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
24.  Financial  additionality.  Metro  rail  projects  in  India  have  been  largely  financed  by 
sovereign-backed  loans  from  development  financial  institutions,  or  public  sector  banks.  The 
nonsovereign loan from ADB will expand KMRL’s funding sources, and have a demonstration effect 
to help reduce the risk perception of such projects (particularly the expansion of existing networks) 
and build confidence in the market. This will attract both domestic and international financiers to 
the sector. ADB also mobilized meaningful commercial cofinancing from LEAP for the project. 
 
25.  Nonfinancial additionality. ADB’s engagement will improve KMRL’s institutional capacity. 
Involvement in the processing of the nonsovereign loan, such as in due diligence and commercial 
negotiations, gave KMRL the opportunity to familiarize itself with the process of raising finance on 
a commercial basis, which will help it adopt a sustainable, market-based approach to the funding 
of future capital expenditure. In addition, compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009) will result in the project adopting internationally recognized E&S standards that are not 
required under domestic laws. ADB’s involvement also contributes to enhancing gender-sensitive 
planning to ensure that women have access to metro services that are better tailored to their needs.

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
32.  ADB categorized the investment in compliance with its Safeguard Policy Statement as 
follows: environment (category B), involuntary resettlement (category B), and indigenous peoples 
(category C).13 
 
33.  ADB undertook due diligence and reviewed the potential E&S impacts of the project, and 
the measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for them, as discussed in the safeguard 
reports and plans. Independent and qualified consultants conducted an E&S compliance audit, an 
initial environmental and social examination (IESE) for phases 1A and 1B, and a social compliance 
audit (SCA) with a focus on state government-led land acquisition, compensation, and labor 
practices. The E&S measures, and the institutional capacity and commitment of KMRL to manage 
the  project’s  E&S  impacts  are  deemed  adequate.  The  institutional  capacity  will  be  further 
strengthened to ensure that management systems and resources are in place to implement the 
agreed actions and ascertain compliance with the Safeguard Policy Statement and other social 
requirements. 
 
34.  Environmental safeguards. Key construction environmental impacts and risks include 
noise and vibration, dust, potential damage to cultural heritage assets, danger to health and safety, 
deterioration  of  surface  water  bodies,  increased  traffic,  and  solid  and  liquid  waste.  During 
operations, key environmental impacts will include noise and public safety risks. Environment, 
health, and safety (EHS) risks during construction are managed through the project’s construction 
EHS management plans and procedures, with standard mitigation measures for the anticipated 
construction EHS impacts. Based on the findings of ADB’s assessment, the management plans 
will be strengthened to ensure compliance with the Safeguard Policy Statement requirements. 
 
35.  A noise model was developed for the project’s operations and is presented in the IESE. The 
model assumed a worst-case scenario and identified minor exceedance of the relevant guidelines 
at three locations. KMRL has embedded noise and vibration control measures in the project’s 
design and will commit to implementing additional measures to minimize noise impacts during 
operations. These commitments will be incorporated into the environmental management plan. 
 
36.  A segment of the project passes through Champakara Canal (adjacent and in parallel to an 
existing bridge), which is connected to the aquatic habitats of the Vembanad Kol Wetlands, a 
Ramsar site.14 The construction methods used and the design of the segment that crosses the 
canal were optimized to minimize disturbance to the flow of water in the canal. Further, impacts on 
the Ramsar site are not expected to be significant since the project segment lies within Kochi City, 
which  is  highly  urbanized.  Anticipated  residual  impacts  are  addressed  through  measures 
incorporated in the project environmental management plan. 
 
37.  Significant effort went into the project’s alignment design to avoid religious structures. 
However, some community property resources, including temples and statues, were found to be 
within the project’s right-of-way in phase 1A. The main structures were not affected, and KMRL 
compensated reductions in lot size and losses of minor assets such as parking spaces and 
boundary walls. The properties maintain the same functionality as before the project impact.

38.  Involuntary resettlement and indigenous people safeguards. The SCA of prior actions 
for phase 1A land acquisition and planned activities for phase 1B assessed compliance with 
national and local legal requirements, and the requirements of the Safeguard Policy Statement—
Safeguard Requirement 2 (involuntary resettlement) and Safeguard Requirement 3 (indigenous 
peoples). For both phases, land is being acquired by the state government on behalf of KMRL. 
Phase 1A land acquisition has been assessed as undertaken not in anticipation of ADB loan and 
therefore national and state legislation was applied. Phase 1B land is being acquired during the 
tenor of the loan and the Safeguard Policy Statement requirements will apply in addition to state 
and national laws. The audit found that the land acquisition is being carried out in line with legal 
requirements and is broadly aligned with the requirements of Safeguard Requirement 2. The 
government process includes a detailed social impact assessment (SIA); various compensation 
entitlements which, when combined, met the principle of compensation at full replacement cost; 
cash compensation for losses to livelihoods; consultation and disclosure at various steps, including 
public input to the design to minimize impacts; and public access to a government-managed 
grievance resolution process. Gaps were found—e.g., lack of attention to gender in the process, 
lack of involvement of KMRL in the grievance redress process, and inadequate compensation paid 
to several economically displaced commercial property renters and employees—and assessed as 
potentially creating project-induced vulnerability. KMRL has developed a Livelihood Restoration 
Plan for phase 1A to address livelihoods related gaps in phase 1A land acquisition which has been 
disclosed in line with the Safeguard Policy Statement requirements and developed with appropriate 
 
meaningful consultation with affected people. 
 
39.  The state government will undertake land acquisition and compensation for phase 1B once 
the SIA for phase 1B is finalized; a draft SIA is currently under review by KMRL. KMRL will be 
required to submit to ADB a Resettlement Plan for Phase 1B related to land acquisition prior to any 
impacts occurring as a result of Phase 1B land acquisition. 
 
40.  The SCA found that the land acquisition for phase 1A affected 399 households or 1,356 
individuals. Of these, 27 individuals experienced physical displacement or loss of more than 10% 
of productive assets. For phase 1B, for which the land acquisition legal process has only just begun, 
the  draft  SIA  indicates  that  126  individuals  will  be  affected  through  physical  and  economic 
displacement; this will be verified during the census and asset inventory, which is yet to be 
undertaken. Given that the total number of displaced individuals is not expected to exceed 200 
individuals, the project’s total involuntary resettlement impacts are deemed not to be significant and 
in line with the criteria for involuntary resettlement category B safeguards. 
 
41.  The project is based in a dense urban area where various ethnic groups reside together but 
with individual property attachments. The audit and IESE found that very few people in the project 
area could be identified as belonging to scheduled tribes, and that these were part of the broader 
urban community with no attachment to communal resources, rights, or claims based on their 
identity. Safeguard Requirement 3 is not triggered for phases 1A and 1B. 
 
42.  Effective gender mainstreaming. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development 
(1998), KMRL incorporated measures to promote gender equality and/or women’s empowerment 
in its business, including (i) child-feeding booths and diaper-changing tables at new metro stations, 
(ii) station noticeboards for third parties to communicate support services for survivors of gender-
based violence, (iii) a corporate gender policy developed and implemented, and (iv) technical 
internships for women. KMRL will submit periodic reports to ADB. 
 
43.  KMRL will comply with national labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection 
Strategy (2001), will take measures to comply with the internationally recognized core labor

7 
standards. KMRL will report regularly to ADB on (i) its and its contractors’ compliance with such 
laws, and (ii) the measures taken. Information disclosure and consultation with affected people will 
follow ADB requirements.15 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
44.  KMRL was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
45.  The proposed loan is within the medium-term, country, industry, group, and single exposure 
limits for nonsovereign investments. 
 
D.  Assurances 
46.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),16 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of India has 
no  objection  to  the  proposed  assistance  to  KMRL.  ADB  will  enter  into  suitable  finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
47.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$55,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to Kochi Metro Rail Limited for the Kochi Metro 
Extension Project in India, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
Masatsugu Asakawa 
President 
13 September 2021

metadata.Subject: The project entails the extension of the existing 25.16 kilometers (km) of metro rail (built in phase 1) in Kochi, in India's state of Kerala. The project will improve mobility, livability, and the urban environment by supporting the provision of a clean, safe, disaster-resilient, and inclusive transport system.The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.This document dated September 2021 is provided for the ADB project 54126-001 in India.
